item.title: I want to get into property development for the first time, what sort of mortgage do I need?
item.description: We don’t want to use bridging finance as this seems really expensive, but we would be looking to sell the property after we have done the refurbishment - can we get buy-to-let mortgage to do this?
item.content:encoded:
I want to get into property development for the first time and I’m not sure what sort of finance I need.

I am married with two small children, I don’t work but my husband is full time and earns a decent salary as a banker in London.

A friend of mine is in a very similar situation and we’d like to get into doing properties up and selling them on together.

We have both done this a couple of times with our own houses in the past, and enjoy it.

We are thinking of setting up a company to do the developments through, which would have my husband, me, my friend and her husband as directors.

We don’t want to use bridging finance as this seems really expensive, but we would be looking to sell the property after we have done the refurbishment – probably between six and 12 months after we buy it.

We’ve built up a deposit equal to 25 per cent of the property we want to buy. My husband and I have a mortgage on our home as do our friends.

Can we get buy-to-let mortgage to do this? Please advise us on the best way to do this.

By email. 

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Get buy-to-let mortgage advice with the This is Money mortgage service

Sarah Davidson, of This is Money, replies: Property development and buy-to-let have been profitable for investors over the past 20 years, but both require careful management to get right.

Buy-to-let can go wrong very quickly if you purchase the wrong type of property for the tenant demand in the area, with even two or three months unlet meaning you fall behind on your mortgage payments. 

Similarly with property development, you need to be absolutely sure you understand the local market and deliver the refurbished property to the standard that buyers in the area want and will pay for - there's no point doing a swanky family home in a student area for example. 

Once you are comfortable and sure that you want to proceed, you should consider taking independent advice from a specialist finance broker with experience helping first-time developers and landlords. 

Most mortgage brokers don't get involved with arranging specialist finance themselves, and are likely instead to refer you to someone with the right expertise. 

There are several elements to your situation that you need to think about carefully. To help, I've broken them down into stages. 

Setting up a company

This can be a good idea if you and your friend are going to be doing the developments together, but you should get professional tax and legal advice to help you structure how you plan to take any profits out of the company, as this could affect other elements of your finances - child tax credits for example. 

There are also different types of company, some of which may be more or less suitable for what you're planning. 

Limited company buy-to-let comes in different forms, and has become far more popular recently because of changes to the way personal landlords are taxed. However, usually these companies are simply a special purpose vehicle designed to house the property and income - they won't necessarily come with the long list of responsibilities that owning and directing a company brings. 

These can include legally having to file accounts, board meetings, making tax digital, and if you have employees  - there is auto-enrolment and payroll to consider among other things. 

Finance

It's important to understand that finance lent against property comes in a plethora of different forms depending on what you plan to do with the property in question.

Residential mortgages (the cheapest) are for those wanting to live in the property themselves, buy-to-let bought in your own name is the next cheapest and is only given when you plan to rent out the property. 

More expensive is limited company buy-to-let which nevertheless still requires to you let out the property. 

Within buy-to-let there are also niche areas such as HMOs - houses in multiple occupation - this is where you rent out individual lockable rooms to separate tenants on separate tenancy agreements. 

 For the sort of project you describe, it sounds as though you should be looking at taking a light to heavy refurbishment loan

Commercial mortgages apply when there is a business being run from the property and these are more expensive still.

There is also bridging finance which has traditionally been used to cover the cost of moving house if you buy your next home before you've sold your previous one.

Bridging has always been around but over the past seven years or so, it has matured considerably with a range of banks and professional though small specialist lenders now offering bridging loans. 

Ten years ago you would have paid 2.5 per cent a month for a bridge, whereas now - depending on the amount of equity you put into the property, some lenders will charge just 0.6 per cent a month plus an arrangement fee which is typically between 1 and 2 per cent of the loan amount.

There is also development finance, typically used where the property is in a dreadful state and needs a complete overhaul or where you plan to knock down a property to build a new one  in its place, or where you have bought land and plan to do what's known as a 'ground up' development. 

In between development finance and bridging there sits a range of niche funding options including bridge-to-let, light and heavy refurbishment funding and auction finance. 

Doing up a dive 

For the sort of project you describe, one option would be taking a light to heavy refurbishment loan for the period in which you want to do up the property, which you would then repay on its sale.

These loans can be anything from around 0.6 per cent a month to 1.5 per cent a month and the price you pay will depend on the specifics of the deal. 

Generally, lenders offering this type of product will lend up to 70 or 75 per cent loan-to-value so you'll need a minimum of 25 per cent deposit to put in yourself. 

The more equity you can put into the deal, the lower the rate you'll be offered. You can't search these loans however, as usually they are priced personally for you and your circumstances. 

It's also important to be sure that you can get the work done in the time frame you agree at the start, as some lenders charge extension fees if you go over the initially agreed loan term, others will charge you penalty fees on top.

The loan amount will be calculated on either the existing value when you purchase the property or some lenders will lend against your projected sale value, known as gross development value.

Your exit from the loan is key to getting approved - you'll need to demonstrate that similar properties in the area are selling at the price you expect or if you plan to keep the property, that you will definitely be able to get a buy-to-let mortgage to refinance to when the refurbishment is complete.  

Specialist lenders tend also to operate through brokers only, some of whom will be able to get you cheaper rates than brokers who don't deal with these lenders all the time - so this is why it's really worth tracking down a specialist with a good reputation. 

Experience and access

While you may have done up your own homes, both you and your friend would still be classed as first-time developers or landlords which drastically reduces the number of lenders willing to give you finance.

There are a few however, so find a broker who specifically helps inexperienced landlords and developers who has a good relationship with these lenders. 

Before you leap into development however, I would suggest speaking to a quality independent mortgage broker who operates in the residential and buy-to-let markets which are far more heavily regulated and offer you consumer protection if things go wrong. 

The danger with going straight to an unregulated broker is that they may help you get the finance but if things don't work out, you could end up severely damaging your finances. So get the full picture looked at by a qualified adviser before you sign on the dotted line. 

We've asked David Hollingworth, of fully regulated independent mortgage broker London & Country, to answer your questions from his perspective. 

He says: As you’ve recognised, the finance options for those looking to refurbish and develop property will generally work in a different way and at a different price from those on offer for traditional buy-to-let landlords.

However, the products are really designed to do different things and the criteria that will be applied will reflect that. 

Buy-to-let is primarily designed for those looking to purchase or refinance property that will be let out as a longer term investment, generating an income and providing potential for capital appreciation over time. 

Short-term funding is a more commercial finance option for those seeking to develop and refurbish property to then resell at a profit. As a consequence rates will typically be higher than you’d expect on a buy-to-let mortgage in the longer run.

 If there is no intention to let the property out at all, that is likely to be enough to result in buy-to-let lenders turning the case down

If there is no intention to let the property out at all, that is likely to be enough to result in buy-to-let lenders turning the case down. Even if there was an intention to let there could be some sticking points though.

One of the primary issues for buy-to-let lenders is that they will typically require the property to be in lettable condition when you buy it. 

They want to be sure that the property will be suitable for letting from day one, as they will put a good deal of focus on the expected rental income when deciding how much a prospective landlord can afford to borrow.

That alone will rule out the use of most buy-to-let mortgages for refurbishment purposes and lenders will conduct a valuation to double check. 

This will be carried out by an independent valuer who will be required to identify if the property is in suitable condition to allow it to be let as well as making an assessment of what that rental income is likely to be. 

That will depend to a degree on the level of refurbishment that is required but it sounds like the focus here is on adding more significant value and therefore is presumably more than a lick of paint.

Some lenders allow you to refurbish first 

There are some buy-to-let lenders that do offer mortgages designed for landlords that will need to carry out some refurbishment of the property before it is let. 

These will typically be designed to assist those that simply need some light refurbishment before being let.

For example Saffron Building Society offers a product designed for those wanting to purchase a property in need of light refurbishment and can release additional funds once work is completed and re-inspection bears out the projected end value. 

The work needs to be completed within three months and the niche rates are still higher and will carry an early repayment charge for at least a year depending on the product.

Another limiting factor for your situation is that this product is not available to those wanting to purchase through a limited company. This is still a more specialised area of lending in the buy-to-let market with specialist lenders tending to be the bigger players. 

However that doesn’t necessarily make them more amenable to refurbishment projects. For example, Kent Reliance will lend to limited companies but does still expect the property to be lettable. 

It might consider allowing the most basic of sprucing up but will put a retention on the funds if anything more significant is required, which would make a purchase impossible for many.

The buy-to-let lenders that might look at refurbishment and limited company lending such as Shawbrook Bank will also want to see evidence of experience of this kind of refurbishment or other property investment.

Ultimately your scenario doesn’t really fit with buy-to-let and you will find more options from those offering bridging and short-term funding options. Lenders such as Shawbrook, and others including Precise Mortgages which has a bridge-to-let product and Castle Trust which offers a flex refurb plus other bridging specialists are more likely to have products to meet your needs.

Although the annual rates are higher on short-term lending, rates can be available from around 0.70 per cent per month. 

That underlines how important it will be for you to have a very clear project plan with realistic timelines, as the exit plan will have a bearing on overall cost of the finance.

item.title: How to buy your dream home for less? When to negotiate, what to offer - and why you may consider paying over asking price
item.description: Research from Barclays Mortgages has revealed that 51 per cent of those who bought a home for the first time in the past five years regret not negotiating before purchase.
item.content:encoded:
After years of rising house prices, nearly all of the major indices are beginning to point to slowing house price inflation and in some cases, even a dip in prices. 

Anecdotal evidence from agents suggests that some buyers are already feeling a lot more confident at putting in a cheeky offer well below the asking price, but many sellers feel they've already priced low to secure a sale and don't want to drop any further.

This is reflected in the falling number of property sales across the country - transactions are slowing down and fewer people are selling each month. Potential sellers are also holding off marketing their homes while prices come down.

The flipside of this means there is little choice of properties to buy and while the heat may be coming out of house price inflation, prices are not cheap in most areas by any stretch of the imagination. 

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Compare mortgage rates and get the best deal with the This is Money mortgage service

First-time buyers still want to get on the ladder as soon as possible. So what is the best course of action if you really want your first home but you want the best possible deal?

We have asked Paula Higgins, chief executive of independent lobbying body The Homeowners Alliance, to answer your questions.

I really want the house but should I offer asking price if house prices generally are falling?

The news that average house prices are falling for the first time in eight years is sure to be music to the ears of millions of would be home buyers. 

In a market where prices are heading downwards it is much easier for a buyer to feel confident enough during the negotiation process to go in with an offer below asking price. 

However, sellers have a not-so-secret weapon on their side - the widely-known fact that demand is by far outstripping supply. When deciding whether to offer asking price it’s important to look at the norm in the neighbourhood you are considering buying in - not the wider housing market. 

While market trends are useful to get an overall picture they don’t always give insight into what’s happening in specific areas of the country or the specific village or road the house is on. Sought after areas of a city will remain sought after regardless of what the general picture is showing so if you’re looking to buy a house in an area where buyers always outstrip available properties it’s important to bear that in mind if you don’t want to keep losing out on houses in your chosen location. 

What information do I need from the estate agent if I want to negotiate?

Check how long the house has been on the market. If it’s been listed for a while this suggests other people think the property is overpriced. 

You should also check whether the asking price has dropped at all since it’s been on the market as this is a likely sign the property is struggling to sell.

Have there been offers on the property already? The estate agent cannot by law tell you what these offers have been but they may be able to give an indication of whether they were very close or way off which could help you pitch the price right. 

Find out about the seller. Do they want to move quickly? Have they already found their next house? If they are keen to move before a baby arrives or for a job then they are much more likely to be receptive to a lower offer. 

Often sellers value the right kind of purchaser even more than price, especially if they’re in a chain. First-time buyers are chain free and if they can show they are ready to move fast with a mortgage in principle in place, they will be a much more attractive proposition than a second stepper in a chain, so use this to your advantage.  

Find out if the property is being marketed by several agents. If this is the case you can be sure the agent through which you’re making a viewing is much more likely to encourage the seller to accept a lower offer - agents naturally want to ensure they get the commission ahead of their competitors. 

What’s a sensible offer to make? 

Do your research. What have recent sold prices of similar houses been in the local area? If it is much lower than asking price but there is little evident difference, pitch that price with your reasoning. 

Again it really depends on the local market, competition and how much you want the house but look at offering between 5 and 10 per cent lower than the asking price initially. 

Buyers often fall into the trap of thinking they have to throw everything at a property as they only get one chance but this isn’t the case. Agents are obliged to put your offer to the seller and if a higher offer is made by another buyer they will come back to you to tell you and give you a chance to reconsider your offer. 

According to the agent there’s plenty of interest in this property, should I make a high offer to be safe?

Be conscious of estate agent tricks. In a sellers' market where the number of willing buyers outstrips the number of properties on offer you may find the agent is trying to induce a panic among interested parties in order to increase bids. 

Stay cool and remember regardless of the market or the property, you can only afford what you can afford. Avoid getting yourself into financial difficulty simply because you got caught up in the moment. 

Can I stop the vendor accepting someone else’s offer if they gazump me? 

Unfortunately not. While gazumping is an unpleasant practice - and a growing concern according to our latest survey - it is not illegal. Sellers naturally want to get the highest price for their property and, on occasion, that means they’ll accept a higher offer even when they’ve already agreed to yours. 

There are some steps you can take to avoid being gazumped however. Make clear your offer is subject to the property being taken off the market. This should reduce the chances of being gazumped. 

Getting to know the sellers can also help; if you’re in contact with them regularly they will find it harder to accept an offer from a stranger. Showing you’re serious by pressing ahead with your survey is also a good idea.

You should also consider taking out home buyer insurance which will help you to recoup some of the costs if the sale does fall through. 

FIRST-TIME BUYERS ARE RELUCTANT TO HAGGLE ON HOUSING 

Research from Barclays Mortgages has revealed that 51 per cent of those who bought a home for the first time in the past five years regret not negotiating before purchase.  

Figures on property purchases made through estate agent Countrywide between April 2016 and April 2017 show that one in five (21 per cent) British first-time buyers paid over the asking price for their property. 

In England and Wales, it’s not Londoners but those in Yorkshire and Humber who proved to be the most likely to go over the asking price with almost a third, 29 per cent, paying more than the initial selling price. 

In Scotland, the figure is even higher at 40 per cent but this reflects the fact that properties are often purchased through the sealed bid system.

The Barclays research claimed that a huge 91 per cent of first-time buyers who purchased within the past five years, believe there is not enough negotiating advice available from trusted sources.

I want to gazunder my previous offer as prices in the area are coming down – how do I do this without losing the property? 

Before approaching the homeowner with a lower offer you’ll need to establish why you’re doing so. If a survey has found problems that will be costly to rectify or you’ve uncovered information, perhaps about plans to the surrounding area, which you know will impact on house prices then you have a justifiable reason to go in with a lower offer and the owner may be receptive to this. 

If, however, you just want to try your luck because you’ve read house prices are falling you’re playing a dangerous game. House price activity changes regularly; just a few weeks ago most indices reported house price growth. 

Tread carefully so as not to risk losing the home you’ve spent months trying to buy. 

I can understand negotiating the price down in London, but is it something I could get away with where prices are much lower? 

Remember, a house is only worth what someone is prepared to pay for it. It’s a cliche but it’s true. Just because a property is priced much lower than its equivalent in the capital would be doesn’t mean it’s priced fairly for its area or, indeed, for current market conditions. 

If you considered all of the above and compared it with other properties for sale in the area and you think you could get it for less then offer less. 

Is price the only thing I should be negotiating? What about the condition of the property and white goods? 

Many sellers will try to get you to up your offer by throwing in things to the deal such as white goods. Try not to be overly influenced by this. It’s worth remembering that unless they are almost brand new, within warranty and have guarantees that are transferrable, white goods tend to be worth very little. 

Should I do this myself or should my solicitor look after this? 

Usually your solicitor will conduct any further negotiations relating to the deal however, whether you’re negotiating on a price for the property or for additional extras sometimes it can be helpful to speak directly with the sellers. 

Be warned, agents and solicitors are usually against this but negotiating in person can be a more straightforward approach. And if you click with the owner it could work out even better. 

What about legal fees – can I negotiate on those too? 

You can’t usually negotiate but you can shop around and it’s essential that you do so. Choosing the wrong solicitor can cost you hundreds of pounds. You can compare conveyancing solicitors using our free tool. 

What if I find myself in a sealed bids situation? 

If you are forced into a sealed bids situation, as can often happen in a booming market, make sure you stick to your budget and, if you are considering increasing your offer, speak to your broker or mortgage lender first to ensure you have the finances in place.

item.title: Sticking your buy-to-let into a limited company to save on tax is increasingly popular... but here's why you should beware doing that
item.description: Using a limited company to own buy-to-let is unlikely to be worth it unless you're buying four or more properties, new research estimates.
item.content:encoded:
Using a limited company to buy or hold buy-to-let property has been tipped by some as a possible solution for staying profitable after landlords began to lose tax relief earlier this year.

But new research suggests that using a limited company is only worth it if you're buying four or more properties.

Existing landlords would need to have even larger property portfolios to make switching from personal ownership to a limited company worth it.

There are different costs associated with owning property through a limited company or personal ownership. For example, mortgage costs are usually higher on limited company buy-to-let, the way properties are taxed in each structure is different, and the costs involved in holding buy-to-let properties are different with each model. 

All of these must be weighed up to determine which leaves the owner better off.   

Mortgage broker firm Private Finance crunched the numbers and found that a landlord earning £46,010 annually - from both a £35,000 base salary plus £11,010 in rental income - will have £36,194 in take home income if purchasing an average two-bed property as an individual after tax and mortgage costs have been deducted.

If the same landlord purchased through a limited company, they would earn £34,825 in take home income - £1,369 or 4 per cent less.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Reduce your buy-to-let mortgage costs by remortgaging with the This is Money mortgage service

Private Finance’s calculations suggest even larger scale landlords could be better off remaining as personal investors. 

A landlord with five rental properties, earning £90,050 in total income (a £35,000 salary and £55,050 in rental income) would have £53,768 in take home pay once mortgage and tax costs are deducted when acting as an individual.

If the same landlord was to repurchase these homes under a limited company, they would have £54,584 in take home pay. 

Once capital gains and stamp duty costs are taken into account they would be left with just £5,374.

Spreading these one-off payments across ten years, take home pay would be £49,663, more than £4,000 less per year than operating as an individual. 

Shaun Church, director of Private Finance, said: 'The option to invest through a limited company has come under the spotlight recently as landlords look for ways to offset recent tax changes. 

'But landlords shouldn’t rush into this assuming it’s a safe bet for saving money.'

Mortgage costs for personal and limited company borrowers 

Mortgage rate Loan size* Monthly payments Annual payments Annual payments as % of net income
Personal borrower 1.92% £144,034 £230 £2,765 8%
Limited company borrower 3.41% £144,034 £409 £4,912 14%
*Based on a 75% LTV interest-only loan on the average UK two bedroom house price (£192,034 Zoopla)
** Rates are the mean of the three best-buy rates available at 12 June 2017

Get an adviser to look at your situation 

Whatever you decide to do, it's worth speaking both to a specialist tax adviser and an independent mortgage broker who will assess your personal situation and advise on the best approach for you.

Using a broker to look at your mortgage costs can also help mitigate some of the dent that losing tax relief has on your income. 

They can also advise on how using a limited company would affect those costs.

Church said: 'Limited company mortgage products are available through a handful of smaller lenders, resulting in higher rates compared to personal borrowing. 

'Larger landlords might find the tax benefits associated with limited company ownership outweigh the higher cost of mortgage borrowing, but each investor is different and there’s no one-size-fits-all solution.'

Why are some landlords choosing limited company buy-to-let? 

Until April this year, private landlords who owned properties in their own names could deduct both mortgage interest and other allowable costs associated with a let property from their rental income before calculating how much tax is due.

This meant the income they had to declare to HMRC was much lower than their rental income, keeping their costs down and keeping many in a lower income tax bracket.

But since 6 April 2017 landlords have begun to see the amount they can write off for tax purposes drop by 25 per cent each tax year until 2020 when they will have to declare all of their rent as income, pay income tax on the total and then claim back for 20 per cent of it as a credit.

However these changes don't apply to buy-to-lets owned by a limited company. Because these properties are viewed as a business, all expenses can be written off for tax purposes.

Landlords can still take an income in the form of a dividend and will pay tax on this only - in theory cutting their tax bills significantly - but they need to watch out for the tax on taking those dividends or eventually accessing any profits rolled up within the company.

For landlords who already have buy-to-let properties, one option is to repurchase into a limited company structure. 

But be warned, this incurs two major tax bills: capital gains and stamp duty, making it an inadvisable move for landlords with a small number of properties who do not have much to gain from being in a limited company.

LIMITED COMPANY BUY-TO-LET ADVANTAGES 
Number of properties Personal borrower Limited company borrower
Two properties

Gross income (salary + rental income) £57,020 £57,020
Annual mortgage interest costs £5,531 £9,823
Total tax bill £10,902 £7,117
Net income £40,587 £39,764
Three properties

Gross income (salary + rental income) £68,030 £68,030
Annual mortgage interest costs £8,296 £14,735
Total tax bill £14,753 £8,276
Net income £44,981 £44,704
Four properties

Gross income (salary + rental income) £79,040 £79,040
Annual mortgage interest costs £11,062 £19,646
Total tax bill £18,604 £9,435
Net income £49,374 £49,644
Cost of running a limited company (£315) has also been deducted when calculating take home income for limited company borrowers

When does it become worth it? 

Limited company landlords can subtract mortgage interest costs from their rental income before calculating their corporation tax meaning limited company borrowers will have a significantly reduced tax bill.

Having less to pay in tax eventually outweighs higher mortgage costs, but in the example above used by Private Finance, this is only achieved once four or more properties are purchased.

SIX THINGS TO THINK ABOUT 

 1. If you already own buy-to-lets and want to transfer them to a limited company you will trigger a sale and repurchase, incurring capital gains tax, stamp duty plus the surcharge plus legal, valuation and mortgage fees.

2. Companies have running costs, incur corporation tax and potentially business rates, require accounts to be formally filed and directors to be appointed. Board meetings have to take place and liability is assigned. This creates an added layer of responsibility for landlords choosing the limited company route.

3. While some lenders price buy-to-let mortgage rates consistently for personal owners and limited company purchases, on the whole, rates for limited companies are higher and they incur higher fees.

4. The tax implications are complicated depending on whether and how you earn any other income. Everyone's personal tax liability will be different so it's really worth getting independent tax advice.

5. Dividends are subject to a different tax regime from earned income and have recently attracted the attention of the Chancellor who had indicated the tax-free dividend would fall next year from £5,000 to £2,000. This follows recent hikes to the tax rate on dividends. However, when the snap general election was announced, the policy proposal was put on hold - and remains so for the moment. 

6. The rules governing buy-to-let are not set in stone and could change again in the future if the Government wishes.

item.title: How much does my electric fan cost to run? I've been leaving mine on all night and am worried about my energy bill
item.description: As it’s been so hot, we’ve had it on throughout the night and during the day at weekends so are we going to be hit with a massive price rise to our energy bills?
item.content:encoded:
We’ve been running our electric fan all night for the past week to try and stay cool during the heat wave, but I’m slightly concerned about how much money this is going to add to our energy bill.

We’ve had it on throughout the night and during the day at weekends - how can I work out how much is it likely to add to our bills?

Rebecca Rutt, of This is Money, replies: The weather has been exceptionally hot this week with the warmest June day recorded since 1976 on Wednesday and temperatures hitting 33.9C in London.

As the majority of UK homes aren’t fitted with air conditioning units, to combat the rising temperatures many people will have been relying on electric fans to try and stay cool.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Can you save hundreds by switching energy bills? Compare prices in your postcode

There has even been a run on electric fans and almost all major retailers have sold out as desperate consumers try and get hold of one.

If you’ve got one at home, and it's been on a lot recently, you may now be wondering how much this might add to your electricity bills. 

The exact cost to your bills depends on a few factors. The first is the kind of fan you have and the amount of energy it uses. To find this out you need to check the ‘wattage’ or number of watts as it's more commonly known as this tells you the average amount of power the fan needs to operate.

Secondly, the price will depend on the number of hours you’re using the fan for and lastly the kind of energy tariff you are signed up to and the price per unit of electricity you pay.

We asked Energyhelpline to estimate the average cost and a spokesperson said running a fan for 12 hours a night would cost between 5p and 14p in total.

This is worked out by taking an average fan, which has a watt of between 25 and 75, and looking at the average price of a unit of energy from a big six provider at 16p. 

To work out the cost, it multiplied the cost of the unit of energy with the average watt for the fan and calculated that a fan with a wattage of 25 would cost an average of £0.004 per hour while a fan with a wattage of 75 would cost £0.012 per hour.

Therefore if the fan was running for 12 hours a night, this would cost between 5 and 14p and for an entire week this would add on a maximum of 98p to your electricity bill – if you ran the fan for 12 hours every night.

To work out exactly how much your fan is costing you can check this energy use calculator which tells you how much you will pay per hour depending on the watt and how much your pay per electricity unit.

Alternatively if you have a smart meter you can easily see how much energy it is using by looking at the difference between your usage when the fan is on and then when it is switched off. 

By 2020 all homes that want them will have smart meters so fears about unexpectedly high bills after using more energy than usual will be a thing of the past.

item.title: The easiest and most difficult places in the UK to pass your driving test revealed
item.description: Want to better your chance of passing your driving test? Avoid the West Midlands if you can. That's according this heatmap of practical test pass and failure rates, with data from the DVSA.
item.content:encoded:
Want to improve your chance of passing your driving test? Avoid the West Midlands if you can.

That's according to a new heatmap of practical test pass and failure rates, based on data provided by the Driving and Vehicle Standards Agency.

According to the figures, just 48 per cent of the 1.3 million tests taken by learners last year ended up with new drivers being granted a licence. At £62 a go, that means failed attempts cost Britons a whopping £42 million. 

Just 40 per cent of learners who took their test in the West Midlands passed, DVSA stats showed, making it the most difficult area in the UK to be granted a licence.

But of all the test centres in the country, it was one in Belvedere, London, that was the toughest to receive a thumbs up from an invigilator.

Just 28 per cent of those who took their practical test there passed - a daunting statistic for anyone who has their driving examination booked at the East London centre.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Can you find cheaper car insurance? Compare with our MoneySupermarket-powered search

A map of the hardest and easiest places to pass was created using the figures by Moneybarn.

Bedfordshire as a whole had an extremely low pass percentage of 41 per cent, while Manchester-based centres also stood out as being difficult locations to get a licence. Centres in Cheetham Hill, Salford, Rochdale and the appropriately-named Failsworth scored an average pass rate of 36 per cent in 2,000 tests - that's 1,280 cases of 'I'm sorry, you've not passed this time' disappointments.

In contrast, thousands of UK residents enjoyed greater success by taking their tests in more rural areas, adding fuel to the suggestions that it's easier to pass in areas with less congestion.

THE UK'S HARDEST & EASIEST TEST CENTRES TO PASS

HARDEST TEST CENTRES TO PASS 

1. Belvedere, Greater London: 28% pass rate

2. Garston, Liverpool: 30% pass rate

3. Wanstead, Greater London: 32% pass rate

4. Barnet, Greater London: 33% pass rate

5. Erith, Greater London: 33% pass rate

6. Cheetham Hill, Greater Manchester: 33% pass rate

7. Birmingham (South Yardley), West Midlands: 34% pass rate

8. Wednesbury, West Midlands: 34% pass rate

9. Salford (Fire Station), Greater Manchester: 35% pass rate

10. Barking (Tanner Street), Greater London: 35% pass rate

EASIEST TEST CENTRES TO PASS 

1. Golspie, Highland Council: 80% pass rate

2. Mallaig, Highland Council: 77% pass rate

3. Ullapool, Highland Council: 76% pass rate

4. Duns, Scottish Borders: 72% pass rate

5. Thurso, Highlands: 71% pass rate

6. Kyle of Lochalsh, Highland Council: 71% pass rate

7. Llandrindod Wells, Powys: 71% pass rate

8. Malton, North Yorkshire: 70% pass rate

9. Whitby, North Yorkshire: 70% pass rate

10. Orkney, Orkney Islands Council: 70% pass rate

Source: Moneybarn

In England, Cumbria and Northumberland had two of the highest national averages in terms of pass rates in the region of 60 per cent.

But that's nothing compared to the ease with which learners passed in the Orkney Islands - there, success rates were at a national high of 70 per cent. 

Rural parts of Scotland, including the Highlands, Shetlands and Scottish borders, all boasted pass rates above 60 per cent, too. 

The statistics also showed that male learners were more likely to pass their practical test, though the tables are flipped when it comes to taking the theory test.

The Limehouse C test centre in East London had the highest theory test pass rates (54 per cent) while the lowest were in Bradford, with 42 per cent passing the examination. 

According to the DVSA, overall pass rates were four per cent higher in 2015/16 than the previous year.

It means that some 600,000 budding motorists were unsuccessful in their attempts at the cost of £62 each last year, a collective £41.9 million. 

However, of those who do pass their test, 48 per cent pass first time, meaning they only have to incur the test fee once.  

Shamus Hodgson, MD of Moneybarn, said: 'Whilst, the average national pass rate has increased by four per cent, built up areas are still showing themselves to be particularly difficult for learners, whether it’s because of extra traffic, complex road signage, or added pressure in a busier environment. 

'It will be intriguing to see if this remains the case, once amendments are made to the practical test later this year.'

Changes will be introduced later this year and include an extended independent driving section from 10 to 20 minutes, which will include periods where drivers will need to follow directions given by a sat nav.

The practical test will also do away with age-old manoeuvres, like the 'reverse around a corner' and 'turn in the road' tasks - instead, they will be replaced by day-to-day scenarios, such as driving into and then reversing out of a parking bay.

The DVSA and Department for Transport are also expected to give their verdict on whether learners will be allowed to take to the motorway as part of driving lessons. 

A consultation on the proposal help new drivers understand the demands and etiquette of driving on the UK's fastest-moving roads came to a close in mid-February.

8 IN 10 DRIVERS WANT LEARNERS TO HAVE MOTORWAY ACCESS

An overwhelming majority of motorists believe learner drivers should be allowed to take driving lessons on the motorway with an approved instructor in a dual-controlled car, according to an RAC survey of 2,000 licence holders.

Eight in 10 (79 per cent) were in favour of the Government’s proposal to let learners gain experience on the UK’s fastest roads before they pass their tests.

A similar proportion (78 per cent) believe the proposals will lead to an improvement in the driving standards of newly qualified drivers when using the motorway network. Some 19 per cent think they will not make any difference and only 3 per cent believe they would worsen standards. 

RAC road safety spokesman Pete Williams said: 'The RAC supports the proposal to allow learner drivers to have the option of motorway driving lessons. 

'We would not, however, be in favour of making such a measure mandatory as many learner drivers do not live in an area which has access to the motorway network. 

'In addition, those drivers that live in regions furthest away from a motorway are less likely to drive on one on a regular basis.'

item.title: How can I check if I had PPI on a mortgage settled 20 years ago? I don't even remember the name of my lender
item.description: I bought my first house in 1990 and I think I paid out PPI for it but I don't know how to check. I can't remember the lender and I don't have any of the paperwork.
item.content:encoded:
I took out a mortgage in 1990 on a property in Gloucester. 

I sold the house in 1997 / 1998 and settled the mortgage. I suspect I was sold PPI as it was my first house and I was very naive, but I cannot remember who the lender was. How can I find out? 

PD. By email.   

Rebecca Rutt, of This is Money, replies: PPI, or Payment Protection Insurance, is a type of insurance policy that was attached to millions of loans.

This included mortgages, credit cards, personal loans, car finance and store cards and many of those who had it were unaware they were paying for it.

As it was mis-sold in many cases, billions of pounds has now been paid back by the banks to those affected. 

But the Financial Conduct Authority has now said that after 29 August 2019 no further claims will be allowed to be made for mis-sold PPI.

In your case you think you may have been paying for PPI on your first mortgage but as it was almost 30 years ago, you can't remember who the lender is.

Usually you could check your credit file to see all of your borrowing over the last six years – even if the account was closed – to get the name of the lender.

You could then approach the lender you had accounts with and ask for a copy of the agreement and the terms and conditions and if you found you had been paying for PPI you could make a claim to get it paid back.

But in your case as it was such a long time ago you no longer have the documents or name of the lender.

We asked the charity Citizens Advice where you stand.

Citizens Advice consumer expert, Kate Hobson, said: 'Most people will be able to find out who their mortgage lender was through the land registry, but it's not guaranteed.

'For a small fee, you can search for your old home on the Government's land registry database. 

'Lenders usually register properties they have agreed mortgages for.

'If you are able trace your lender you can contact them to check if they have the paperwork which would show they sold you PPI. Given the length of time that has passed, there is no guarantee the lender will have kept these records.'

Rebecca Rutt adds: There is no official cut-off time for how far back you can claim for PPI but banks are only required to keep this information on file for six years.

This means it may be harder to claim if, such as in your case, you paid for the policy more than six years ago and don't have the paperwork anymore.

However, if you can get your hands on it, you can still make a claim and some firms may keep these records for longer than six years.

If you are successful in tracking down the lender, and you can see from the documents that you were paying PPI, you will need to make a claim before August 2019.

It's easy to do and you don't need to pay a third party to do it for you. Our guide lists step-by-step instructions on how to reclaim your PPI and has free template letters you can use.

item.title: Find out how much different mortgage lenders will let you borrow: New calculator reveals how home loan offers can vary by £150k
item.description: Dwell has come up with a new breed of mortgage calculator that reveals, after the user has plugged in their specifics, how much different banks and building societies will be prepared to lend.
item.content:encoded:
Ever been confused by the dark arts of mortgage brokers who seem to know which lenders will lend less and who will lend more? 

Despite all the talk of tightened lending criteria over the last few years and househunters getting no more than 4.5 times their salary as a home loan, it still seems lenders have very different approaches - and it's only mortgage brokers who can divine the size of loan we will get.

One online broker has afforded borrowers some much-deserved transparency with a new mortgage calculator that reveals, after the user has plugged in their specifics, how much different banks and building societies will be prepared to lend. 

And for one borrower (see case study below) the discrepancy between the most and least generous turned out to be £150,000.

Dwell is one of a few recently launched online mortgage brokers but the only one so far to offer this particular tool. At the moment it only compares the top 10 mortgage lenders, but it takes two minutes to get an accurate idea of how much you personally could borrow from the likes of Halifax, NatWest, Barclays, Santander or Nationwide.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Compare mortgage rates and get free advice with the This is Money mortgage service

Instead of giving you an estimate like other calculators, Dwell's system updates in real time using data provided by these 10 lenders.

This includes detailed criteria such as how they calculate self-employed income or whether they will lend if you've got a black mark on your credit profile, for example. 

Each lender has a different attitude to risk and will lend people very different amounts. This is a huge issue as it can lead to people missing out on the properties they hope for.

The tool also sets Dwell apart from the other two online brokers - Trussle and Habito - which allow you to apply for a mortgage online and then suggest the best mortgage product for you. At this stage you are then passed over to a real person who gives you mortgage advice over the phone.

Dwell's application process is similar to this and includes advice from a human being, but its calculator shows you the range of offers available to you before you apply.

The firm's chief executive Pradeep Raman says: 'What often isn’t explained and certainly isn’t clear to many mortgage applicants is that each lender has a different attitude to risk and will lend people very different amounts.

'This is a huge issue as it can lead to people missing out on the properties they hope for.'

Why do other calculators not work like this? 

Mortgage lenders used to work out how much you could borrow based on a multiple of your annual income, with about four or five times that being pretty typical. 

But new rules brought in during 2014 banned that simple calculation and instead force lenders to base the amount you can borrow on what you can 'afford' - loosely, your income minus your expenses each month leaving room to cover your mortgage repayment.  

There is no hard and fast rule on how this calculation is made by lenders though - with the result that, according to Dwell, the difference between the highest and lowest amount can be more than £150,000.

The firm gives the example of Alex and Fatima, a couple who found it difficult to work out how much they could borrow to buy their first property because Alex is self-employed and Fatima has a car loan.

Alex pays himself a small salary and dividends of £16,000 a year while leaving roughly £50,000 in the company as operating profit before tax over the past three years. Fatima earns £35,000 a year and is committed to paying £200 each month towards her car finance loan.

Using the calculator they found that Woolwich from Barclays will lend them a joint mortgage of £415,000 - a whopping £188,100 more than the loan RBS is prepared to offer the couple at just £226,900. 

This doesn't mean that Barclays will lend the most to everyone - it simply seems that Barclays' lending criteria favour their particular circumstances.

Where one lender might like customers with full-time employed salaries and no credit card debt, others are more concerned about your age and how long you want to repay the mortgage over.  

The calculator also trumps the traditional comparison sites which rank deals based on how cheap the rate is and whether they have a commercial arrangement that sees them paid a commission by the lenders they feature.

Additionally, the deals pulled up when you search for a mortgage using a price comparison website are only the advertised rates and products - you might find that you don't qualify for them at all.

Steve Tigar, chief executive of Money Dashboard - one of This is Money's top 10 financial apps - used the Dwell service to organise his first mortgage this month after struggling to get anywhere with price comparison sites. 

'I think they are terrible, a complete waste of time,' he says. 'There is not a modicum of personalisation to the search results and typically you get punted through to a single broker who doesn't bother to follow up once you fire over your enquiry.'

As a result Steve opted to use Dwell and says he found the service simple and easy to use. You can compare online mortgage brokers here. 

A word of warning to those looking to do the whole thing online however - mortgage lenders themselves still haven't caught up with technology so no matter how whizzy the search and communication functions with your broker are, you'll probably still be required to deal with piles of paper. 

'Despite Dwell using some pretty smart tech, the lenders still require an inordinate amount of paperwork,' says Steve. 'It was a genuine headache trying to pull together months of bank statements as I haven't received paper bank statements for over a decade.'

DOING THE MORTGAGE ONLINE 

Steve Tigar used Dwell to arrange his mortgage recently and said the experience was 'outstanding'.

My family moved to Edinburgh five years ago and we have all fallen in love with the city. It felt like the right time to settle down and buy a family home. We've been saving for quite some time and had a rough idea of what we could afford. We weren't sure, however, which lender would be right for us and the Dwell service looked fascinating. 

They promised to find relevant products quickly, which is exactly what we were looking for. And they weren't charging a fee either which was appealing giving the extortionate transaction costs involved in purchasing a property.

They combine the latest technology with human expertise to deliver a really outstanding service. There were quite a few moving parts during the transaction, so it was great to be able to fire over WhatsApp messages to the Dwell team that were actioned very quickly, which saved me the hassle of calling or popping into a broker's office.

We knew we could get a larger mortgage, but we didn't want to over extend ourselves, so we decided not to allow ourselves to be tempted by that and instead chose to take the Barclays Springboard mortgage. It was an attractive rate for a low deposit, allowing us to deploy our savings on home improvements.

item.title: Should you ditch diesel? As drivers worried by pollution and a crackdown start to turn away, here's what you need to know
item.description: With the T-Charge coming to London in October and Clean Air Zones predicted across the UK by 2019, should you be jacking in your diesel car? We take a look at how drivers are reacting to the news.
item.content:encoded:
In 1998, then-Chancellor Gordon Brown said diesel car owners should pay less tax because their vehicles produced less carbon dioxide than equivalent petrols.

In 2001, he followed that up with a C02-graded car tax system that heavily favoured diesels. Fast forward two decades and the very same vehicles successive governments pushed on the back of their environmental credentials now have a black cloud of emissions-related levies looming over them.

And drivers have reacted to the U-turn, with analysis suggesting that the nation is already beginning to ditch diesel cars in fear of a raft of new penalties.

But are they making their decision in haste? We lay out what is happening and look at what could come next for diesel cars and their owners.

Are we turning away from diesel cars? 

There's been a plethora of data released in recent weeks suggesting strong evidence that Britons are worried enough about diesel car ownership to start turning away from it. 

The month-by-month new-car registrations figures released by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders - the UK's automotive industry representative - has shown a declining demand for diesel models in recent months, especially since the turn of the new year.

Despite all new-vehicle sales being up 1.1 per cent in the first four months of 2017, diesel car registrations are down by 6.4 per cent.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Can you find cheaper car insurance? Compare with our MoneySupermarket-powered search

Last month, diesel registrations dropped by an astronomical 27.3 per cent - though the SMMT put this down to the introduction of new VED rates on April 1 that increased car tax costs for the lowest CO2-emitting models, which also had a more moderate impact on sales of petrol (down 13 per cent) and alternative-fuel (down 1.3 per cent) vehicles.

While the industry body refrained from blaming the government's recent focus on the fuel type for the significant decline, it did say last month that Britain was at risk of grinding to a halt if politicians continued to demonise diesel. 

NEW DIESEL-CAR REGISTRATIONS TAILING OFF COMPARED TO PETROL
FUEL TYPE REGISTRATIONS YOY JAN 2017REGISTRATIONS YOY FEB 2017REGISTRATIONS YOY MAR 2017*REGISTRATIONS YOY APR 2017 REGISTRATIONS YOY 2017 TO DATE 
Diesel -4.3%-9.2%+1.6%-27.3% -6.4%
Petrol+8.9%+5.8%+13.2%-13.1%+6.8% 
AFV +19.9%+48.9%+31.0%-1.3%+23.8%
Source: SMMT 

AutoTrader, the nation's most popular online car sale platform, has reported a decline in the number of car buyers actively searching for diesel vehicles in the last six months.

The drop off began on November 16 2016, the same day there was widespread deliberation suggesting that diesel cars could face city charges as part of the government’s tougher plans on tackling air pollution.

This trend continued in the beginning of 2017, potentially as a response to comments from the Transport Secretary, Chris Grayling, that warned against purchasing diesel cars in February.

Interestingly, despite this recent decline, more car buyers still search for diesel more than any other fuel type on Auto Trader. There were some 1.9million searches for diesel vehicles in March, compared to 1.4million for petrol in the same month.

Buyacar.co.uk, another used-car selling platform, claims that three out of five current diesel owners intend to choose a different fuel type next time they change their car.

Of the poll of 1,000 drivers, 48 per cent owned a diesel car. Just 40 per cent of those existing diesel owners said that they planned to buy another when the time comes to change their car with the majority opting for petrol instead. Just five per cent said they'd turn to electric.

AREAS WITH THE BIGGEST INCREASE IN DIESELS COMING ONTO THE MARKET

 1. Essex – 43% increase

2. Southampton – 41% increase

3. London – 40% increase

4. Manchester – 39% increase

5. Birmingham – 36% increase

Source: Wizzle 

Wizzle, which helps private owners sell their cars to dealers, claimed that selling times for diesel cars have doubled from six to 12 days in 2017, while there has been little to no impact on the time it takes to shift a petrol model - typically three to four days. 

Boss, Sébastien Duval, said there has also been a 'volatile pattern' in terms of the value of diesel cars compared to petrol from week to week.

He said: 'The pattern we are seeing suggests that motorists in areas which are likely to be affected by things like future penalties for using or parking a diesel car are hedging their bets by selling now. 

'We don’t think the bottom has fallen out of the diesel market but it does seem that when it comes to buying cars for stock dealers are definitely exercising more caution than last year.' 

CarGurus, an online car buying site that recently launched in the UK, said it had seen an 8.1 per cent decline in enquiries for diesel cars in the last three months.

A spokesperson for the site said: 'Consumers are naturally reluctant to make a big purchase when the outlook is uncertain and so are responding by looking for petrol and hybrid vehicles.'

Motorway.co.uk, also an online car selling platform, polled 750 diesel car owners and found that 19 per cent are planning to offload their cars in the next 12 months specifically to avoid potential additional taxes.

It also predicted a 10 to 15 per cent fall in average used diesel car prices in the next year.  

What's the problem with diesel?

Studies have found that there is a very strong link between the harmful emissions produced by diesel vehicles and premature deaths. 

New research published in the journal Nature in the last week showed that a minimum of 38,000 people a year worldwide die early because NOx emissions produced by diesel vehicles exceeded official limits in real driving conditions.

Last year, the Royal College of Physicians estimated that air pollution cuts short 40,000 lives a year in the UK alone, with those suffering from cardiovascular disease and lung conditions most susceptible.

In November, the High Court ordered ministers to cut NOx levels in the 'shortest time possible', leading to a raft of new suggestions to kerb diesel-vehicle use in some of the most congested regions. 

What additional charges do diesels face?

London T-Charge (October 2017): The £10 T-charge - to be introduced on 23 October this year - will work alongside the existing £11.50 congestion charge, and will affect petrol and diesel cars with pre-Euro 4 engines (built before January 2006).

London Ultra Low Emissions Zones (April 2019): London's T-Charge might not be around for long: Mayor Sadiq Khan said he plans to replace it with the first ULEZ in Central London from 8 April 2019, as part of plans to trim the capital's harmful nitrogen oxide (NOx) outputs.

Poll

What will fuel the next car you buy?

  • Diesel 6526 votes
  • Petrol 6096 votes
  • Hybrid 2196 votes
  • Electric 1125 votes

Now share your opinion

  •  
  •  
  •  
  •  

It would see the fee to drive a pre-Euro 4 petrol car (registered before 1 January 2006) or a pre-Euro 6 diesel (registered before 1 September 2015) within the zone rise to £12.50 a day, meaning a daily cost of £24 combined with the congestion charge.

As with the congestion charge, this only effects the very centre of London, however, the Mayor has floated the idea of extending the £12.50 ULEZ all the way out to the North and South Circular roads. This would encompass a substantial residential area.

You can see if your vehicle is effected by going to the TfL online checker. 

Clean Air Zones (2019): The government's recent Air Quality Plan outlined proposals to introduce Clean Air Zones - similar to the London ULEZ - across major towns and cities in the UK.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs wants zones to be introduced in 27 high-traffic-volume areas in places,  such as Birmingham, Leeds, Nottingham and Manchester, from 2019. It hopes this will help bring the nation's emissions into line with current EU requirements.

If this used the same stringent policy put forward for London's ULEZ, this would mean owners of pre-Euro 6 diesel cars and vans built before September 2015  would have to pay a £10 charge, as would drivers of pre-Euro 4 petrol cars made before January 2006.

Diesel surcharge for London parking permits (in action): An increasing number of London councils are adding extra charges to the cost of parking permits if you own a diesel vehicle. 

In 2015, Islington Council introduced a flat £96 per year diesel surcharge on top of the existing cost of all residents parking permits, which are already graded on C02 emissions. Camden and Merton in South London will also charge extra if you own a diesel vehicle.

Higher parking fees for diesel cars in London (in action): Motorists in Westminster have had to pay a 50 per cent diesel surcharge for on-street parking since April this year. 

All diesel cars - no matter their Euro emissions standard - will be charged extra, which works out at 12p per minute compared to just 8p a minute for petrol vehicles. 

Diesel car tax increase (Potential move):During the latest Spring Budget Statement, Chancellor Phillip Hammond said he was going to 'explore the appropriate tax treatment for diesel vehicles' ahead of his next Autumn 2017 Budget.

A hike in tax for diesel owners could be sought via two different channels: raising fuel duty on diesel (which is currently the same as petrol standing at 57.95 pence per litre), which would make every mile driven more expensive, or adding a diesel surcharge to the Vehicle and Excise Duty rates owners have to pay each year.

Diesel scrappage scheme (idea being discussed): The government is working on plans to introduce a 'targeted' scrappage scheme as part of new clean air directives in order to meet the EU pollution limits.

When introduced, ministers hope it will remove 9,000 of the most polluting diesel vehicles from Britain's roads, along with 6,000 old petrol cars that also have high emission outputs.

The incentive is expected to push eligible motorists in the direction of electric models. It's not clear what age or level of diesel engine it would target and the Government would need to balance this against the potential cost and scope of the scheme, for example including recent euro 5 diesels could send costs spiralling.

Emissions stickers in France (in action): Thinking of taking your car across the channel? From the beginning of this year many French cities - including Paris, Lyon and Grenoble - require vehicles driving within designated 'environmental zones' to display a sticker on the windscreen rating their pollution output.

The Crit-Air stickers cost £3.60 (€4.18), including postage to the UK and can take up to six weeks to arrive.

Failure to display one could result in a fine of £117 and the highest polluting vehicles are banned from the zones at specific times. 

I've just bought a new diesel car - am I going to be hit with higher charges?

It's unsurprising that many drivers are turning their back on diesel after the noise made by campaigners and the raft of statements made by ministers in the last six months, but what about those drivers who have just purchased a new model?

Brand new diesel cars on sale today - which have to meet Euro 6 emissions standards - are said to be among some of the least-polluting vehicles on the road.

These should not be confused with older diesel cars built before September 2015 that many of these surcharges are targeting. This includes the Euro 5 era VW models that have been at the heart of the ongoing emissions-cheating scandal.

The euro 5 bracket covers all cars registered new after 1 January 2011. The RAC's Euro standards guide explains: 'The big news for Euro 5 was the introduction of particulate filters (DPFs) for diesel vehicles, along with lower limits across the board. For type approvals from September 2011 and new cars from January 2013, diesel vehicles were subject to a new limit on particulate numbers.

'DPFs capture 99% of all particulate matter and are fitted to every new diesel car. Cars meeting Euro 5 standards emit the equivalent of one grain of sand per kilometre driven.'

But while euro 5 diesels were cleaner than those before them, they still produce more nitrogen oxide than their more modern cousins, with a maximum of 0.18g/km compared to 0.08g/km for the euro 6 cars.

WHAT EURO EMISSIONS STANDARD IS MY CAR? 
Emissions standard Applied to new passenger car approvals from Applied to all new registrations from
Euro 1 1 July 1992 31 December 1992
Euro 2 1 January 1996 1 January 1997
Euro 3 1 January 2000 1 January 2001
Euro 4 1 January 20051 January 2006
Euro 5 1 September 2009 1 January 2011
Euro 6 1 September 2014 1 September 2015

The newer Euro 6 vehicles - both diesel and petrol - are expected to be exempt from many of the additional costs listed above - a point the SMMT says has been missed in coverage of the issue.

Chief executive Mike Hawes said, 'Euro 6 diesel cars on sale today are the cleanest in history. 

'Not only have they drastically reduced or banished particulates, sulphur and carbon monoxide but they also emit vastly lower NOx than their older counterparts – a fact recognised by London in their exemption from the Ultra Low Emission Zone that will come into force in 2019. 

'Some recent reports have failed to differentiate between these much cleaner cars and vehicles of the past. This is unfair and dismissive of progress made. 

'In addition to their important contribution to improving air quality, diesel cars are also a key part of action to tackle climate change while allowing millions of people, particularly those who regularly travel long distances, to do so as affordably as possible.' 

Andy Pringle from AutoTrader, added: 'Millions of car buyers are still searching specifically for diesel cars each month, there are more new cars with clean EU6-compliant engines being sold – and they could be a part of the solution to air pollution.' 

I own an old diesel car - what should I do?

Rob Hull, of This is Money, says: While it remains unclear how many of the diesel-targeting schemes will be imposed, when they will be introduced and which Euro-standard cars will be affected, there's no pressing need to sell just yet, especially if your older vehicle is providing low-cost motoring at the moment.

With many of the larger cars designed for families - especially SUVs and people carriers - predominantly powered by diesel engines, we would hope that ministers will be reluctant to impose massive charges on this section of voters.

You also have to bear in mind that, until recently, the Government had been pre-occupied with championing low-CO2 producing cars and rewarded buyers with lower taxes for those vehicles, which skewed heavily towards diesel ownership. 

To significantly punish those same drivers financially would be extremely unfair, though not beyond the realms of possibility. However, a serious backlash would arrive if owners of relatively modern Euro 5 diesel cars were hammered.

It's without doubt that diesel cars will be a focal point of the government's push to reduce emissions, though. So if you own a two-to-six year old car that has retained plenty of its original value, you might want to part with it sooner rather than later to negate any further dips in used values. This is certainly the case if you live or drive frequently in London where surcharges already exist.

If you own a much older diesel car that's worth very little on the second-hand market, it might be worth holding onto it to see what incentives are offered as part of the scrappage scheme that seems more and more likely to happen. You could receive a healthy discount on a cleaner new model if you hold out.

And what about those looking to buy a new model? If you're still unsure about the future ramifications of purchasing diesel, it could be worth considering taking out a PCP finance deal which has to include a guaranteed-value balloon payment at the end of the agreement that is optional. 

If prices have dipped, you can simply hand the car back to the dealer and let them deal with the sudden drop in value.

How do I work out the Euro standard of my car and how much harmful emissions it produces?

Details of the exhaust emissions produced by the car you own can be found in section 4 on the inside sheet of your V5 registration document.

It lists CO2 (carbon dioxide) emissions as well as CO (Carbon Monoxide), HC (Hydocarbons), particulates and NOx (Nitrogen Oxides), as measured during official EU tests for this vehicle.

An alternative way to find out how much a car emits and its Euro emissions standard rating is to use Next Green Car's handy emissions tool that lets you compare the real-world and official test measurements on all new and used models.

item.title: I want to let a property to a family member and not charge them rent, will I fall foul of any rules?
item.description: Are duties of a landlord different if you are not charging rent? David Cox (pictured), boss of letting agents association ARLA Propertymark, responds.
item.content:encoded:
I have inherited a property which I want to let to a family member but not charge them rent. 

What are my responsibilities as a landlord - are they any different because I'm not making money from this arrangement?

David Cox, chief executive of letting agents association ARLA Propertymark, said: When you inherit a property which you then let out, you are subject to all landlord and tenant law.

You need to ensure you have consent to let the property (from a freeholder in a block of flats for example) as well as appropriate buildings insurance and contents insurance for all the landlords fixtures, fittings and furnishings.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Compare buy-to-let mortgages with the This is Money mortgage service

You must ensure that the home is fit for human habitation, has an Energy Performance Certificate (EPC), a Gas Safety Certificate (if the property has gas), fire alarms on all floors and carbon monoxide detectors in every room where solid fuel is burnt.

You also need to obtain a license from the local authority to let the property (where necessary), protect any deposit received in one of the three Government authorised schemes - the Deposit Protection Service, MyDeposits and the Tenancy Deposit Scheme.

You need to provide the tenant with the Deposit Protection Certificate, a copy of the Prescribed Information and the Government’s How to Rent Guide.

You must also make sure the tenant, and anyone else living in the property, has the lawful right to live in the UK.

These are all required irrespective of whether you are letting the property to a family member, friend or complete stranger and it doesn’t matter whether or not you are charging rent.

There is no legal requirement to have a written tenancy agreement but it is best practice and we strongly recommend that you do as it clearly sets out, on paper, what each person’s rights and responsibilities are whilst the tenant is living in the property.

item.title: My mortgage broker wants me to put my five buy-to-lets into a limited company to save on tax, should I do it?
item.description: Limited company buy-to-let is in vogue - largely down to several structural changes to the way buy-to-let income, gains and purchases are taxed. But is it a good idea?
item.content:encoded:
I became a landlord eight years ago and have built up a profitable portfolio of five properties in the Midlands. 

They’re in my name and I don’t really want to switch them into a company. My broker seems to think this is what I should do though.

They all have buy-to-let mortgages on them, with an average loan-to-value of 82 per cent. What do I need to do given the changes to tax relief? 

Sarah Davidson, of This is Money, says: Limited company buy-to-let is in vogue. This is largely down to the past year seeing several structural changes to the way buy-to-let income, gains and purchases are taxed.

Earlier this month the phased reduction of tax relief on buy-to-let mortgage interest began. Over the next three years, this tax relief will taper and be replaced with a 20 per cent tax credit by 2020, hitting profits for many landlords hard. 

Meanwhile, last year saw not only the introduction of a 3 per cent surcharge on stamp duty payable on the purchase of buy-to-let properties and second homes, but also the scrapping of landlords' wear and tear allowance.

For more on these changes, click here.  

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • For free buy-to-let mortgage advice, contact the This is Money mortgage service

The key to the limited company question is the changes to mortgage interest tax relief and wear and tear. 

The tax relief on mortgage interest changes and the loss of wear and tear apply for landlords who own buy-to-lets in their own name and mean that now, they pay income tax calculated on the rental revenue generated by these properties, not just on the profit they make after they pay mortgage interest.

Thousands of landlords have seen their costs start to rise as a result and mortgage brokers are looking for ways to help mitigate the financial hit. 

However these changes don't apply to buy-to-lets owned by a limited company. Because these properties are viewed as a business, all expenses can be written off for tax purposes.

Landlords can still take an income in the form of a dividend and will pay tax on this only - in theory cutting their tax bills significantly but they need to watch out for the tax on taking those dividends or eventually accessing any profits rolled up within the company.

This is a VERY simplistic way of explaining the differences, however, the industry and media have seized upon limited company buy-to-let as a silver bullet solution. 

It is not. There are lots of considerations to take into account. Here are just a few:

1. If you already own buy-to-lets and want to transfer them to a limited company you will trigger a sale and repurchase, incurring capital gains tax, stamp duty plus the surcharge plus legal, valuation and mortgage fees.

2. Companies have running costs, incur corporation tax and potentially business rates, require accounts to be formally filed and directors to be appointed. Board meetings have to take place and liability is assigned. This creates an added layer of responsibility for landlords choosing the limited company route. 

3. While some lenders price buy-to-let mortgage rates consistently for personal owners and limited company purchases, on the whole, rates for limited companies are higher and they incur higher fees. 

4. The tax implications are complicated depending on whether and how you earn any other income. Everyone's personal tax liability will be different so it's really worth getting independent tax advice.

5. Dividends are subject to a different tax regime from earned income and have recently attracted the attention of the Chancellor who had indicated the tax-free dividend would fall next year from £5,000 to £2,000. This follows recent hikes to the tax rate on dividends. However, following confirmation of a snap general election in June, this policy proposal has been dropped for the moment from the Finance Bill. Read more here.

6. The rules governing buy-to-let are not set in stone and could change again in the future if the Government wishes. 

Whatever you decide to do, it is a good idea to get independent financial advice AND independent tax advice. Mortgage brokers are qualified to find you the best mortgage but that doesn't mean they are qualified to give you tax advice. For this, you'll need a specialist accountant.  

Rob Bence, is a landlord himself and is also co-founder of investor forum The Property Hub. He gives his view on your situation: 

In my opinion, you're right not wanting to move into a limited company. 

When the former chancellor George Osborne announced plans to introduce cuts to landlord tax relief back in 2015 the limited company route was touted as the panacea. 

Indeed, thousands of landlords have now opted for this route - latest figures from Countrywide show a fifth of all buy-to-lets are now held by company landlords. 

But I think many were too quick to see this as the easy option. 

The limited company route is not without its flaws. You would have to pay capital gains tax on any capital growth and although you have an allowance it's unlikely to cover that. 

There’s also stamp duty to consider. You’d effectively have to buy the properties as a limited company from yourself as an individual so you’d be liable for stamp duty, including the 3 per cent surcharge. 

You'd have all the administration work of setting the company up and managing its accounts. Furthermore, while there are more limited company mortgages coming to market, they do tend to be priced at higher rates than individual mortgages.

The most important thing to do it to understand how your tax position will change. Will you move into a higher tax threshold or will you stay below? 

Now that landlords will pay tax on their income, not just their profits, many are being pushed into higher tax brackets. If this is the case you’ll want to reassess your portfolio.

Do your sums. Once the full tax burden is in place (it is being phased in and won’t be fully in play until 2020) will all of your buy-to-lets be profitable?

Consider selling any properties that don't cover their costs.

Look at all your mortgages and make sure they are the best products available to you. Cash flow is now more important than ever and looking at your mortgages is one way of improving this.

If you’re going to remortgage look to lenders that have a transitional arrangement in place. Mortgage criteria is currently tighter than ever for buy-to-let as a result of new rules from the Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority. 

These rules mean lenders are implementing stricter stress tests and landlords are required to prove they can secure higher rents in order to access funds. 

The PRA has however allowed lenders to put in place transitional arrangements meaning borrowers can remortgage under the criteria that was in place before the new rules came into play. 

In other words you can take out a mortgage at a lower rental coverage calculation. Not all lenders are making the most of this but Ipswich Building Society recently became the latest lender to do so.

It’s worth noting however that most buy-to-let lenders will only lend up to 75 per cent loan-to-value. Leveraging beyond 82 per cent - as you are - will be difficult and expensive as products with a higher LTV also come with a higher rate.

Consider using your spouse to limit your taxes. This is not as Machiavellian as it sounds. If your spouse doesn't work then using his or her tax allowance would be worth looking into.

Finally, make sure you are aware of any tax deductible expenses. Mortgage broker fees and lender arrangement fees, for example, are tax deductible as are any funds spent on repairs or maintenance.
